justification: The article states that participants ‘identified as severely depressed at pre-treatment (with Beck Depression Inventory-II scores of greater than 24)’ were analysed, indicating BDI-II was the instrument used to quantify depression severity.

In the description of inclusion criteria, the authors note an ‘Initial Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) score of 14 or greater,’ showing that the original BDI was employed to assess level of depression.

For the Persons et al. (2006) sample, eligibility required ‘at least four sessions of symptom data on the BDI or the Burns Anxiety Inventory,’ demonstrating that the Burns Anxiety Inventory served to measure anxiety symptoms.
When reporting outcomes, the study compared change trajectories on ‘Brief Problem Checklist …’ indicating this checklist was used to assess youths’ symptom/problem levels.
The same section lists ‘Top Problems Assessment’ among the principal symptom measures, showing it operationalised the construct of youths’ presenting problems.
Outcome analyses included the ‘Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL),’ evidencing that CBCL scores represented children’s internalising and externalising symptom levels.
The authors reference the ‘Youth Self Report (YSR)’ as one of the symptom measures, indicating it captured the child’s own report of psychological symptoms.
Later the paper notes ‘Lambert’s OQ-45 … have sufficient empirical support,’ identifying the OQ-45 as a routinely used system for monitoring overall mental health outcomes.

measured_by: Partners for Change Outcomes Monitoring System (PCOMS)
justification: The same sentence cites the ‘Partners for Change Outcomes Monitoring System (PCOMS)’ as an empirically supported outcomes monitoring tool, linking PCOMS to the assessment of treatment progress and functioning.
